one of the perhaps best interventions

one of the most common diseases of the
neglected tropical diseases are

can result in malnutrition they can

schistosomiasis can raise the rate of

well how does that happen
schistosomiasis is a particularly

the parasite can actually result in

likely to contract HIV AIDS during
sexual intercourse so preventing these

all what else is needed is actually

in order to avoid the transmission of

just focusing on one disease or another

there's not a massive incremental cost
it doesn't take a lot more time to do
and yet it actually has a domino effect

and overall improving lives and

one of the greatest successes in global
Public Health particularly in subsaharan
Africa over the last decade is Rwanda so
it's no coincidence that I moved there
with my family three years ago in order
to help make a contribution because it
was one of the countries where I never
faced corruption and where I saw that
government really took a firm lead in
making a vision of good health for all a
reality
and they've done this a couple of
different ways they've actually made use
of financing from the global fund to
fight AIDS TB and malaria from the
presidential uh emergency plan for AIDS
relief and uh other donors in order to
really improve the quality of overall
health care so unlike other countries
which get thrown money to just focus on
AIDS and all their resources suddenly
scramble and and look at AIDS Rwanda has
been very smart about it and they've
actually said we've got to take a look
at our burden of disease we've got to
improve overall health care at the
health center level at the health post
level and they've gone out and slowly
but surely really ramped up the overall
level of care at for for the average
rwandese and what does that actually
look like on the ground well one of the
major plans for Rwandan Healthcare is
called health mutal so rwandans are
expected to spend about $2 per capita
per year for a suite of services so if
they show up with their health Mutual
card they're provided malaria care basic
infection immunizations all of the
basics actually get done for them
they've essentially bought into uh an
insurance fund and Rwanda is one of the
few countries in subsaharan Africa that
has a plan quite like it and has the
percentage of participants that that
Rwanda has got today so this has
actually been one of of the key
ingredients to their success I've had
some concerns of my own about reaching
the very poorest of the poor who don't
have that $2 but the government of
Rwanda and some of the donors have
actually stepped in and said for those
who are extremely poor we will cover
your health care because we recognize
for you to be productive you've got to
have access to healthcare what they're
striving for of course is universal
healthcare they want to make sure that
there's health care for all and that no
one's discouraged from showing up at a
hospital or a health center if they're
terribly ill if they don't have health
insurance and this is a really tricky
political football in Rwanda right now
but overall they've been doing a really
good job figuring out how to get this
online one of the original challenges
that one of my teams noticed was
actually that the health mutel card
itself required a photograph and a lot
of people didn't have photographs so one
of the very simple solutions that my
Access Project team rolled out was just
putting webcams in the health centers on
the health mutell computers a 1995
webcam ended up dig taking these digital
photographs for free and removing this
barrier to accessing health mutel and we
saw the uptake increase dramatically at
the sites that started using just this
webcam the Access Project which is a
project that I've LED in Rwanda for
several years and actually which is
currently completely led by rwandz it's
a huge success story because when I
started up this project we had a fully
expat team so we had a lot of Americans
who were over living in Rwanda working
with the government side by side
literally at the desk with the minister
of Health as the scaling up began in
Rwanda but over time we managed to build
the Capa capacity of rwandz to take over
the project today the entire project is
led by rwandans and the private sector
is actually taking notice so fizer for
example the pharmaceutical company has a
global Health fellows program and every
year they are sending the Access Project
some of their key person Personnel
Personnel in management and accounting
and strategy who are working with this
Rwandan team in order to further make
improvements to the Health Care system
in Rwanda that's a great example of
public private partnership another key
partner that we have in Rwanda in the
field is General Electric through the GE
Foundation GE has actually done some
amazing things in Rwanda and across
subsaharan Africa and places like Ghana
as well they've actually said we're not
going to give away our worst products
we're not going to give away our
cheapest products we're not going to
give away last year's products we're
going to take our top-of-the-line
products we're going to send experts out
to the field and figure out what are the
needs in health centers in hospitals and
if those countries and those Health
Centers and those hospitals can
demonstrate that they're competent and
conscientious and that they can manage
and maintain the hardware that we're
willing to put in place we will send out
teams we will train them in the
utilization of this hardware and we will
put it out there in the field and I've
seen GE already pour millions of dollars
this way into Rwanda and it literally
has changed the quality of health care
for hundreds of thousands if not
millions of
people investments in global Health
aren't just good for poor countries
investments in global Health are
something that's actually good for the
world and when people scratch their
heads and wonder well we're not spending
perhaps enough money on Health Care here
in America what are we doing spending
money on helping healthc care improve in
a poor country like Rwanda the answer is
that it's an interconnected world as we
saw with swine flu and with SARS by
improving surveillance and improving
treatment by improving uh what happens
to emerging diseases and existing
diseases in poor countries we're
actually improving the overall health
the world and moreover we're also
improving productivity to levels where
countries can finally climb out of
poverty and not become countries that
are dependent on our aid but rather
become countries that are improving
their tax space starting to pay in for
more and more of their public services
and ultimately become bigger consumers
of American Products so an investment in
health is a key step to ensuring that
the world does not have the same problem
s that it's had for hundreds of years
and finally getting over that incredible
hump and providing us with a world in
which kids don't die when they're less
than 5 years old of preventable and
treatable diseases when mothers don't
die in child birth because these are
health issues which don't just impact
the communities in which they are
occurring it impacts the whole world it
makes everybody more susceptible to to
coming across diseases which we really
don't want to see and we don't want to
see at the levels of pandemic that we've
seen uh just in the recent past take a
look at something like HIV AIDS it looks
like it originated in central
Africa perhaps as much as a hundred
years ago perhaps even longer ago but we
didn't know about it until the early
1980s because that's when it came up on
our radar screen if we've been investing
in Health Care Systems more effectively
in central Africa and in subsaharan
Africa we probably could have picked up
on that emerging epidemic much much
earlier and we could have done more to
Stave off that epidemic from reaching
our
